Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Tools for how to analyze primary literature, history of epidemiology, statistical techniques, research design, how to make proposals.

I learned how to analyze and interpret data in the fields of epidemiology and public health. I think these skills will set the groundwork for my understanding of research in the field and enable me to do my own research in the future.
This course was very haphazard and had many knowledge gaps. I learned how to use SPSS a bit. I learned a basic knowledge of public health and some epi terminology.
SPSS, how to present cases, how to conduct case studies

- SPSS
- How to analyze data and articles
- How to become a better memer
SPSS, case studies, analyzing epidemiological cases with more scrutiny and attention to statistical detail
Learned about the basics of epidemiology and was introduced to SPSS. Not a very in depth course, but useful introduction nonetheless

I learned some basic epidemiology concepts, how to use SPSS, and real-life examples of the things we were learning about in class. This course gave me a better understanding of epidemiology research, and I got to practice thinking critically about reported statistics.
I learned how to use SPSS, what chi-square tests are, how to use ANOVA tests, what "tringler" means, and other useful skills/facts.
I learned a lot about epidemiology and public health, and gained valuable SPSS experience! We even had a group presentation, which helped us to develop many skills.
I learned about the various types of work that epidemiologists do and how these are needed for the field of public health. I practiced using SPSS to analyze and interpret data.

Basics of epidemiology, fundamentals of epidemiological research design and execution, how to read and analyze public health papers, how to use SPSS to  analyze data sets and make conclusions of statistical significance.
I learned how to use SPSS and analyze public health statistics
SPSS...lots of SPSS
I learned the basics of SPSS, learned to analyze/spot inconsistencies in data and statistics in journal articles, learned to design a public health study and analyze/critique other designs
Fundamentals of epidemiology; practical knowledge of SPSS
I gained a solid overview of epidemiology!
Great grasp of epidemiology from a practical and academic perspective

Originally thought that this course would be more social science focused, and although it is, it's also very stats-oriented, which was a pleasant surprise! You learn applicable skills such as how to use SPSS and interpret data.
I learned a lot about the practice of epidemiology, how studies are organized and conducted, and how to discuss and critically analyze health data.

The foundations of epidemiology and its tools, including rates of incidence, prevalence, risk ratios and others. For me, this was a great research design class that helped figure out the specifics of how experiments should be conducted and samples should be taken

I learned a general overview of public health. I learned how epidemiology is studied through research. I learned how to use SPSS software to analyze a data set. I learned some basic statistics. I learned how to look at public health studies critically.
This class provided a compelling, thorough overview of epidemiology and pertinent statistical methods.

I now understand more about epidemiology and realize that epidemiology is not the field for me. Although I did not personally enjoy the course topics, I do think that knowing the principles and skills within epi are important.
I learned how to perform basic operations with SPSS, the basics of epidemiology, and how to design and evaluate studies and surveys.
Some of the materials we covered in class were a bit ambiguous and confusing, but that may just be the nature of epidemiology.
Strengths are definitely the class set up and emphasis on group work. I think one way it could be improved would be a little more guidance on how to use SPSS.
This course was not taught in a manner than made much sense. I really enjoyed the first lecture. You need to have a section like space or maybe office hours or just formally teach SPSS.

Strengths: Fun, engaging lectures alternated with case studies was a good way to keep the class going. Dr. White is a joy to learn from.

Weaknesses: Sometimes material became monotonous; midterms were more difficult and detail-oriented than expected

The class is super understanding about what is to be a student and provides a lot of flexibility. The material is also kept interesting by a lot of application scenarios and fun little tidbits of information. However, for someone inexperienced with stats, the class could sometimes move too fast and it was hard to reinforce knowledge on your own.

Strengths: Dr. White is an engaging lecturer--funny, poised, and a joy to learn from. She mixed classes up by having lectures on Tuesdays and case studies on Thursdays. She relayed information/material in a casual, laid back manner that is so different from other Yale classes, making it a unique and ultimately more beneficial experience. The learning environment was highly encouraging and positive.

Weaknesses: Sometimes case studies were too long or too short, and it could be easy to sit back and allow your group mates do most of the work-- don't do this! You won't learn and will be ill-prepared for the final!

Strengths - fun lectures, learned lots of SPSS, got the basics of epidemiology l, hands on

Weaknesses - because half of the lectures are hands on, we dont get a very comprehensive introduction to epidemiology

I liked the structure of alternating lectures and cases, as we learn the material and then get a chance to practice it. I also like that the course teaches us how to use SPSS but through cases, instead of just teaching us theoretical information on how to use it. I also liked that there were various types of assignments, ranging from problem sets and cases to tests and presentations. I felt that this showed us how the material could appear in different contexts and helped solidify concepts.

I loved the format of the course! It was set up so that it was very possible to succeed. I loved that we got to practice the concepts we learned rather than just memorizing lecture notes like in some classes.
I liked having lecture on one day and the case studies on the other day. However, I didnt feel like we got a lot of direction in lecture about the things we would need to do for the psets.

The professor is the largest strength of this course. Professor White is lovely, funny, kind, and very engaging. It is great that she is so invested in getting to know her students and make the class applicable to the work that they will likely do in the future. It was also really useful to learn how to use SPSS and analyze real data. However I would have liked to learn higher level SPSS data analysis skills, I felt that there was certainly room for this class to be more difficult in challenging us in the data analysis portion would be very useful. The lectures were also useful but I felt that given the level and competence of Yale undergrads the class could have been more challenging and we could have dove into more high level epidemiological approaches and topics. In some ways I felt that a lot of the material that we covered I already knew due to my previous exposure to statistics and public health and that the course could have been far more challenging.
I think the strengths of the course were a knowledgable teacher, interesting content, and good applications for many majors/jobs. I think it could've been improved by a little bit more structure.

I loved the lab portion of the class, however I think it could be more structured and with a class this large have more TAs to help out, sometimes the questions were a bit vague/open-ended which either  got us to justify our points or made people confused. Overall, the material was great and delivered well, one of the few lecture courses I felt comfortable speaking up in.
Prof. White will forever be a strength of this course. The lectures can get a bit dull, but they are overshadowed by interactive case studies on Thursdays.
I looked forward to class every week because the professor was perfectly suited for the course. The combination of lecture and SPSS applications/practicals each week made for a good combination.
The weekly practicals were a plus. The lectures were a bit dry and difficult to grasp without independently reading the textbook.

Strengths: Amiable professor, the material isn't too difficult but it's really interesting, a good introduction to public health methods. 
Weaknesses: The statistics parts kind of assumes that you have knowledge of stats walking into the class, so it may be a bit difficult to wrap your head around some concepts, although definitely not impossible.
I felt blindsided by the first midterm, and wish there had been practice tests.
I felt like the course was a bit too big for the type of labs that we needed to do... it was hard at times for the TAs and Professor
The strengths of the class come from the hands-on labs that emphasize analysis of real studies and real data.

Marney is a very nice person and tried to make the class interesting. Although her philosophy of doing-to-learn makes sense, I think that this shouldve been introduced later in the course. Sometimes the directions on psets and in class were vague and made things more frustrating than necessary. 
Although some in class examples used smaller, easier to understand numbers and situations, others used really complex/real life numbers which made it that much harder to comprehend certain topics. In the future, I would recommend using easier example scenarios before delving into real life examples.
The time constraint on the final was unrealistic - creating the spot map alone took a really long time. Reading through the scientific articles took longer than the actual SPSS portion. In the future, having no time constraint or one less section may be a better option.

Strengths: loved the in-class studies, great coverage of topic material, good explanations of the statistics behind the work, course material constantly encourages critical thinking and analysis, great feedback throughout the semester
Weaknesses: more practice with/explanation of SPSS might have been nice
Yes prof White is wonderful and it is a relaxing class.
I would definitely recommend if you are at all interested in going into the fields of epidemiology or public health!
Probably not. It wasnt very difficult but it was overwhelming and I constantly felt lost. The teacher is great but the class isnt organized well.
Yes! Dr. White is an excellent professor, and classes are always enjoyable. She encourages you to be a curious learner.

I think if you have any research, health, stats, or even want to increase your health literacy, this class is a good one to take. However, just be aware that it is helpful to have some basic stats knowledge.
Yes! Dr. White is an excellent professor and the class is fun because of her more laid-back yet still informative teaching style
Yes
Yes! Its engaging and fun

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in the material or to anyone who wants to see statistics used in real-world contexts (without needing an extensive statistics background or learning lots of details about statistics). The material is interesting and not overwhelming, Professor White is great, and the class is engaging with varied assignments to keep things interesting.

No. This course is not good. It is a waste of one of your credits and your time. If you have to take it, it will be boring and useless but not awful. 

This class:

1. Teaches you no useful skills. I don't feel like I've come away knowing how epidemiology - or even SPSS - works. Maybe have 5-10 more equations/definitions memorized, though.

2. Is extremely disorganized and poorly structured. 

The professor:

3. Paternalizes students to the point that it detracts from other students' learning.

4. Is just a bad lecturer. Goes through slides far too quickly, simply reads off of the powerpoint, speaks too quietly for back 1/4 of class to hear.

5. Never seems to have time for students' questions.
Absolutely; it's a great and interesting course taught by a fun professor who really cares about her students.
I would absolutely recommend this course, its very interesting and Marney is awesome!

Absolutely! It is one of my favorite classes I have taken at Yale! You learn so much, but in a way that is far less stressful and more productive than many Yale courses. If you are interested in the subject, definitely take it!
Yes, take it if you are interested in a broad overview of epidemiology and the field of public health.

This class was overall great! Professor White is lovely, a great person to know, and is super passionate about the material. Learning SPSS is very useful and a lot of the topics we cover are quite interesting and applicable. This is also a fairly easy class with a very manageable/low workload that makes this a good fifth class. This class may be too basic for juniors or for those that have strong stats background.
I would recommend, great intro class for epidemiology.
Yes, especially if you are thinking of designing a public health study, this will give you the necessary background
Absolutely; if you have an interest in any branch of public health, this course is a great elective.
I would absolutely recommend this course! Anyone interested in public/global health should take this course.
Definitely

Yes! I would I really enjoyed it, but I wouldn't necessarily have taken it if I didn't have an interest in public health. It's more niche-focused, but you'd still enjoy it even if you didn't like public health.
Yes. Good intro epidemiology class and prof white is super nice.
Yes! This course was perfect for everyone! Professor White is absolutely amazing and her lectures are engaging and fun with her pop culture references. But we definitely learn a lot in this course.
Very tricky. Doesnt seem hard - until you reach half term and you realize because you dont know statistics youre super behind. Just be prepared if you have to take it. Its not as easy as it looks.

I would probably recommend this class to a student who had interest in the subject. I am not very interested in the subject (I took the class for a requirement) but it was fairly enjoyable and I feel that I am better able to read and interpret articles and studies about health concerns.

I absolutely loved this class (and the instructor) - you learn at a great pace with the opportunity to apply skills as you learn them to really solidify your knowledge. You will walk away from this class confident about epidemiology, proficient in STATA (which is the best program), and hating on mayonnaise (for good reason). I would recommend this class to everyone, even those who wouldn't consider epidemiology their cup of tea, as it helps you develop skills to critically evaluate the research of others as well as improve your own future research design/analysis.

If the person is interested in epidemiology or enjoys math/statistics, I would recommend this course. As someone who wants to go into public health, I think that this course gave me some practical knowledge but overall I was not very enthusiastic about the content as the weeks went on.
Yes, definitely! Great class with amazing instructor. You learn a great deal that is helpful knowledge to have both for public health work and in life.
